princeton_ansible.title: Updating Node to Fermium LTS for the lae Role
Drupal 9 desires the pg_trgm extension in postgres. Can we install it?

comments.body:
we do install extensions that in the postgresql role. See postgis example [here](https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/blob/8dd37e2250910a9eedb9d3c1e7c7c8e570d43663/group_vars/postgresql/gcp_dev.yml#L11)

Want me to add it to that PR?

princeton_ansible.title: lockers is not showing up in datadog

comments.body:
The datadog role is included in the production playbook, see https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/blob/0751637888caae46cb9024f6696f78ebc5eec61b/playbooks/lockers_and_study_rooms_prod.yml#L9. When I SSH to the production server, I see datadog config. And when I log into our datadog instance, I see logs: https://app.datadoghq.com/logs?query=service%3Alockers-and-study-spaces&cols=host%2Cservice&index=%2A&messageDisplay=inline&stream_sort=desc&from_ts=1645128053726&to_ts=1645128953726&live=false. 

All the entries in the logs today are labelled `info`, so maybe they are too boring to show up on the default views . . . but my guess is that someone fixed this and forgot to close the ticket. If I'm wrong, and there's more to do here, please re-open it @carolyncole.
@acozine and I have just tested the Playbook for `pdc_discovery`, and this was quite successful!

princeton_ansible.title: Add daily log rotate config to EZproxy Roles

comments.body:
I started to look at this today, but my keys are not on the staging server yet.

On the production server, the logs look like they are getting rotated. There's one log per day and they are mostly timestamped at 23:59. There is no entry in `/etc/logrotate.d` for these logs, and no `ezp.log` file. The `/var/local/ezproxy/config.txt` file has some log directives in it. I'll pick this back up when I can and start with that config.txt file.

There's some minimal documentation at https://help.oclc.org/Library_Management/EZproxy/Configure_resources/LogFile.

ruby-for-archivesspace.title: Correct the `PATCH` example for the REST README.md
Fixing the error in the PATCH example
Restructuring the tutorial into a workshop consisting of three sessions
Document the possible usage of ruby-office1.princeton.edu for participants
Adding documentation for accessing ruby-office1 for the workshop
Ensure that the first session involves ASpace API user authentication
Adding ASpace API authentication to the first session
Restructure the repository into three workshop sessions
Ensure that the ASpace REST API is accessible for aspace.princeton.edu

comments.body:
Unfortunately, this does not appear to be stable, as the Google Cloud Shell containers are going to be restricted from accessing the `staging` server environment: ```bash jrg5@cloudshell:~$ curl -v "https://aspace-staging.princeton.edu/staff/api/" * Trying 35.160.138.106:443... * Connected to aspace-staging.princeton.edu (35.160.138.106) port 443 (#0) * ALPN, offering h2 * ALPN, offering http/1.1 * successfully set certificate verify locations: * CAfile: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt * CApath: /etc/ssl/certs * TLSv1.3 (OUT), TLS handshake, Client hello (1): * TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Server hello (2): * TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS handshake, Certificate (11): * TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS handshake, Server key exchange (12): * TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS handshake, Server finished (14): * TLSv1.2 (OUT), TLS handshake, Client key exchange (16): * TLSv1.2 (OUT), TLS change cipher, Change cipher spec (1): * TLSv1.2 (OUT), TLS handshake, Finished (20): * TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS handshake, Finished (20): * SSL connection using TLSv1.2 / ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384 * ALPN, server accepted to use http/1.1 * Server certificate: * subject: CN=aspace-staging.princeton.edu * start date: Feb 15 02:38:05 2022 GMT * expire date: May 16 02:38:04 2022 GMT * subjectAltName: host "aspace-staging.princeton.edu" matched cert's "aspace-staging.princeton.edu" * issuer: C=US; O=Let's Encrypt; CN=R3 * SSL certificate verify ok. > GET /staff/api/ HTTP/1.1 > Host: aspace-staging.princeton.edu > User-Agent: curl/7.74.0 > Accept: */* > * Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse < HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden < Server: nginx < Date: Thu, 17 Feb 2022 19:49:29 GMT < Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8 < Content-Length: 146 < Connection: keep-alive < 403 Forbidden

403 Forbidden

nginx
```

Using a sample set of 3 Google Cloud containers, I find the following IP addresses:

```bash
jrg5@cloudshell:~/cloudshell_open/ruby-for-archivesspace$ curl icanhazip.com
35.196.122.174
jrg5@cloudshell:~/cloudshell_open/ruby-for-archivesspace$ curl icanhazip.com
35.227.53.111
jrg5@cloudshell:~/cloudshell_open/ruby-for-archivesspace$ curl icanhazip.com
34.139.118.209
```

As this range is far to broad in scope to request any firewall permissions, I am going to request that the workshop exercises please do *not* use the `staging` environment. Should this prove to be too limiting, it should be noted that this still might not be necessary until the second session (scheduled for 03/03/22).
